thread.title: One place has been Googling Brexit more than anywhere else - and it's in Devon

author: Neil Shaw
title: One place has been Googling Brexit more than anywhere else - and it's in Devon
text:
Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get Daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
Devon had the highest Google search interest in Brexit over the past week of anywhere in the country.
Exclusive data provided by Google reveals that between the 23 and the 29 of July Chagford searched for Brexit more than any other UK community.
West Devon - the constituency in which Chagford is situated in - voted to leave the EU in the Brexit Referendum in June 2016.
A strong majority of 54% voted to leave, equating to 48,000 votes. However, in stark contrast a major survey carried out by Devon Live in April found that 15% of leave voters in Devon would change their decision in a new referendum. Read More Cheese and onion crisp shortage thanks to weather and Brexit
The next-most interested places in terms of Google searches were Cambridge, Wembley and Eastbourne. Most of the top places in terms of interest are in the south - the most interested northern city only comes in at 20th place, which is York.
Overall, the most searched Brexit related question so far in 2018 is 'What is Brexit?' - not much of a surprise considering the ongoing confusion over Theresa May's article 50 plans.
According to a Ipsos MORI poll for the Evening Standard, just 30% of adults are satisfied with her performance, a five point fall compared to a month ago. Read More Brexit could leave fish rotting on the quayside
Searches for Brexit peaked at an all time high in the past year on July 9 2018. This was the day David Davis resigned from his post as Brexit Secretary, causing shockwaves across the country.
His resignation letter poured scorn on Theresa May's "progressive dilution" of her Brexit strategy - saying she had handed too much power to the EU leading to a "weak" and "possibly inescapable" negotiating position.
The ex-SAS man warned he had turned into a "reluctant conscript". Like us on Facebook
